body: I'm not a Paulian, there's lots of works forged in his name too, especially those abominations called 1 & 2 Timothy and Titus, which are obvious attempts by the Romans to insert traditional pagan beliefs into Christianity. I in fact get annoyed seeing everyone treat Paul as important as Jesus, if not *more* important in many cases. But what is clear is that the epistle of "James" barely mentions Jesus at all and teaches a works gospel, something clearly opposed in all four gospels as well as Paul. Actually that goes for the Old Testament too, despite the increased presence of earthly punishment.

School me. Thanks

body: No, they are *the* commandment. People lived for millennia without the ten, knowing the real one in their hearts. Making it about the 10 commandments results in legalism, allowing evil if it's not mentioned in the 10 and wrongly forbidding other things based on instructions meant for 3400 years ago that we may either misunderstand or are not applicable. For example "Do not murder" but what if someone is terrorizing your whole community and that's the only way to stop them? Faith and the commandment and principle must guide you, not the old way of written codes and laws.

post.body: Now, obviously I don't think the point is that you *cant* be a Christian and have strong political views (one of Jesus 12 disciples was a Zealot) but when it comes to speaking with our family and friends, and especially our church family it is so important to to be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to become angry. Politics should not divide us.

Because there aren't any. People say "oh, Jesus was a radical leftist", but Jesus want concerned about physical kingdoms, he spoke about the spiritual kingdom, but acknowledged that in this life we are subject to government's and authorities.

Beyond "Render unto Caesar" it speaks of the government's being appointed by God for his purpose as well as the purpose of the government's. I don't recall the exact scriptures but I can find them if you'd like.

body:
First of all this is just Paul, secondly you are twisting that passage far beyond what it is actually saying. His point is 1) turn the other cheek 2) police and such help keep the peace and 3) it *may not be right* but God still allowed it to rise for a reason, possibly to strengthen their faith. I don't see any call to patriotism or nationalism in that, and I doubt Paul actually had a high opinion of a regime that was out to kill and torture him.

> When the governments are just they are Gods ministers of justice against those who do evil, ie: crimes. When governments are not just they go against God and enslave the people. God hates unjust scales; God hates hands that shed innocent blood; God hates false witnesses and people who plan evil. When governments turn these wicked things toward the people they are no longer ministers of justice, and not of God.

Paul was living under the Roman empire, which was definitely NOT right and totally unjust. Assuming Paul wrote this passage, he did so about a regime that loathed him and was literally out to get him and torture him and everyone he knew and loved.

If you want something that actually addresses this question more directly see 1 Samuel 8.

parent.body:
Worship it? No. Support it? Yes, if the government is just.

>Romans 13: 1 Let every soul be subject to the governing authorities. For there is no authority except from God, and the authorities that exist are appointed by God. 2 Therefore whoever resists the authority resists the ordinance of God, and those who resist will bring judgment on themselves. 3 For rulers are not a terror to good works, but to evil. Do you want to be unafraid of the authority? Do what is good, and you will have praise from the same. 4 For he is God’s minister to you for good. But if you do evil, be afraid; for he does not bear the sword in vain; for he is God’s minister, an avenger to execute wrath on him who practices evil. 5 Therefore you must be subject, not only because of wrath but also for conscience’ sake. 6 For because of this you also pay taxes, for they are God’s ministers attending continually to this very thing. 7 Render therefore to all their due: taxes to whom taxes are due, customs to whom customs, fear to whom fear, honor to whom honor.

When the governments are just they are Gods ministers of justice against those who do evil, ie: crimes. When governments are not just they go against God and enslave the people. God hates unjust scales; God hates hands that shed innocent blood; God hates false witnesses and people who plan evil. When governments turn these wicked things toward the people they are no longer ministers of justice, and not of God.

body:
> but if God appoints rulers then those who follow Christ should, naturally, want to support the things God has appointed, right?

Recognize *that* yes but not support the nation in itself, just the plan it's part of. And in any case this "support" applies to *all* of them, not just "good" ones.

> Where does "turning the other cheek" come into play here?

Because if something they are doing is wrong, don't fight back with more evil, just submit to what they require of you as long as it's not wrong.

> You are thinking of this all wrong. Jesus **neither supported** nor condemned a "regime that was out to kill him" because he knew his Fathers plan

Even you realize it subconsciously.

> Jesus willingly submitted himself to Gods will knowing that he would suffer, so your #2 makes no sense.

That's far different from actually approving of what the nations do. Supporting the plan that includes something rising to power is MUCH different than actually supporting the said thing. You are confusing the two thanks to so many centuries of propaganda.

> 1 Samuel 8 is a different story altogether because God told the Jews that HE would be their king and they had no need of an earthly one. The people didn't like that and they wanted a physical, human king to rule over them, which displeased God. This situation is specific only to the Jews and doesn't apply to the other nations of the world.

Why do you say this only applies to the Jews? Is Christ not supposed to be *our* only king too? Is the description of power abuse even by good-hearted people not accurate for gentiles? You seem to want an earthly king or organization to rule over you too, with an excuse that is basically just a retelling of the divine right of kings. They may be allowed in power because it will be used for some purpose, but that *doesn't excuse their behavior*, nor should you support their actions. God raised the pharaoh up for a purpose too. Does that make him right? What about Hitler or Stalin?

body:
> I say it only applies to the Jews because it is literally an account of the Jews asking for a king and God telling Samuel that it was not his plan for them to have a mortal king. It cannot be applied to all christians because it is LITERALLY spoken from God to the Jews and nowhere does it condemn other nations from having kings.

It speaks some pretty negative things against kings in general. I don't see why that doesn't apply to non-Jews, because just look at any example of authority in this world and you'll see how true it is.

> In fact, if what you said was true then the verses that indicate God has set authorities over the nations would make God a liar.

Wrong, again you are confusing making good things out of something bad with that thing actually being good.

> The Jews lived in Egypt under the pharaoh without issue until pharaoh began to crush them under the weight of slavery, after which God sent someone to free them, both to fulfill the prophecy of taking them to the promised land but also because he would not let his people live under oppression. GOD sent someone to instigate the rebellion of the people to escape slavery.

God LITERALLY tells the pharaoh: "*I have raised you up a for this very purpose*, that I might show you my power and that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth". So he allowed something bad to rise to power so that he could make good out of it. That doesn't make the bad good, meaning the pharaoh was still wrong and should not be supported.

> And when we speak of authorities of nations I don't think we can speak of specific people IN MOST CASES. God is the creator of the nations, but man has free will to choose those to whom they hand the mantle of leadership to, though God may appoint certain people for a purpose.

Man can try and start a nation just as much as appointing a ruler in an existing one. We have free will but our thinking we actually have much control over that kind of stuff is an illusion.

> Did God raise up pharaoh? No, I don't think so.

Exodus 9:16

> God raised up Egypt. Egypt chose their leaders in the manner they use. Eventually a pharaoh got nervous bout the Jews and decided to place them under slavery.

He still got someone he knew would do those things into power.

> Did God set up Hitler or Stalin? No. God established the creation of Germany and Russia, but men have free will to do as they please and choose their leaders as they please.

You say he created the nations, but doesn't have any role in what happens with them? That doesn't make much sense. Besides, I think "the governing authorities" means the present authorities, that you say are 100% man's decision.

> Here in the Americas (I do not know if you are American or not) the founding fathers recognized the divine hand of God making it possible for them to fight and win against the most powerful military force on earth at the time, against a king who was for oppressing them.

Which was rebellion against the king and thus grossly violates your requirement of supporting the established authorities! (Indeed, it violates my interpretation too). Does that make the king right? No, it merely means he was established for a purpose. By the way, he would've used the divine right of kings excuse himself.

> Perhaps it was Gods divine plan to set up the United States for the future of the worlds sake during the World Wars

It was allowed to happen, so it was

> or perhaps it was just Gods response to a people who recognized him, worshipped him, followed the statues laid out in his word and called upon him for his divine hand to grant them victory.

You're being fed legends and fairy tales. The real founding fathers were people just like those today. They were not angels and many of them had some quite questionable practices, and most of them were either not christians or in name only.

> if you believe man truly has free will, despite the fact that God knows all both future and past, then your point of view seems skewed, at least to me.

I do, but you vastly overestimate the control our decisions actually give us over the world. Remember Jonah didn't want to go on a missionary journey to a place he didn't like, so his ship sank and he was swallowed by a whale and spit out exactly where he was supposed to go.

> Also understand that my rebuttals contain no malice or anger. I quite enjoy the discussion.

Same

Did God raise up pharaoh? No, I don't think so.

Exodus 9:16

God raised up Egypt. Egypt chose their leaders in the manner they use. Eventually a pharaoh got nervous bout the Jews and decided to place them under slavery.

He still got someone he knew would do those things into power.

Did God set up Hitler or Stalin? No. God established the creation of Germany and Russia, but men have free will to do as they please and choose their leaders as they please.

You say he created the nations, but doesn't have any role in what happens with them? That doesn't make much sense. Besides, I think "the governing authorities" means the present authorities, that you say are 100% man's decision.

Here in the Americas (I do not know if you are American or not) the founding fathers recognized the divine hand of God making it possible for them to fight and win against the most powerful military force on earth at the time, against a king who was for oppressing them.

Which was rebellion against the king and thus grossly violates your requirement of supporting the established authorities! (Indeed, it violates my interpretation too). Does that make the king right? Perhaps it was Gods divine plan to set up the United States for the future of the worlds sake during the World Wars

or perhaps it was just Gods response to a people who recognized him, worshipped him, followed the statues laid out in his word and called upon him for his divine hand to grant them victory.

You're being fed legends and fairy tales. The real founding fathers were people just like those today. They were not angels and many of them had some quite questionable practices, and most of them were either not christians or in name only.

if you believe man truly has free will, despite the fact that God knows all both future and past, then your point of view seems skewed, at least to me.

I do, but you vastly overestimate the control our decisions actually give us over the world. Remember Jonah didn't want to go on a missionary journey to a place he didn't like, so his ship sank and he was swallowed by a whale and spit out exactly where he was supposed to go.

Also understand that my rebuttals contain no malice or anger. I quite enjoy the discussion.

parent.body:
I say it only applies to the Jews because it is literally an account of the Jews asking for a king and God telling Samuel that it was not his plan for them to have a mortal king.  It cannot be applied to all christians because it is LITERALLY spoken from God to the Jews and nowhere does it condemn other nations from having kings. In fact, if what you said was true then the verses that indicate God has set authorities over the nations would make God a liar. God, and Jesus, tell us that while we are on this earth we are subject to the laws and authorities here so long as they do not violate the laws of God. The Jews lived in Egypt under the pharaoh without issue until pharaoh began to crush them under the weight of slavery, after which God sent someone to free them, both to fulfill the prophecy of taking them to the promised land but also because he would not let his people live under oppression. GOD sent someone to instigate the rebellion of the people to escape slavery.

And when we speak of authorities of nations I don't think we can speak of specific people IN MOST CASES. God is the creator of the nations, but man has free will to choose those to whom they hand the mantle of leadership to, though God may appoint certain people for a purpose. Did God raise up pharaoh? No, I don't think so. God raised up Egypt. Egypt chose their leaders in the manner they use. Eventually a pharaoh got nervous bout the Jews and decided to place them under slavery. The Jews cried out and God chose Moses to be his hand and free the people. He hardened the heart of pharaoh so that the Jews, and Egypt, could witness the power of God.

Did God set up Hitler or Stalin? No. God established the creation of Germany and Russia, but men have free will to do as they please and choose their leaders as they please. Men have free will to do evil and subjugate others. Men also have free will to fight against tyranny and oppression. Many people think God has every action of every person mapped out and that we cannot go off script, but this is antithetical to God's love for mankind, which is free will. We may call upon him and he may intervene, but we are not puppets on strings that he controls from heaven above.

Here in the Americas (I do not know if you are American or not) the founding fathers recognized the divine hand of God making it possible for them to fight and win against the most powerful military force on earth at the time, against a king who was for oppressing them. Perhaps it was Gods divine plan to set up the United States for the future of the worlds sake during the World Wars, or perhaps it was just Gods response to a people who recognized him, worshipped him, followed the statues laid out in his word and called upon him for his divine hand to grant them victory.

This sound like where our impasse lies. If you believe that every person their action and thoughts are controlled by God then I can see from your point of view. However if you believe man truly has free will, despite the fact that God knows all both future and past, then your point of view seems skewed, at least to me.

Also understand that my rebuttals contain no malice or anger. I quite enjoy the discussion.

body: I'm referring to myself, who has no talent whatsoever in any area. Even in my areas of biggest interest that I've been doing for years, beginners easily crush me. Everyone I know does what I think is impossible in extremely short times with no sweat. I'm smart, but I have no natural abilities at all, I'm just not wired for anything I like at a fundamental level. And it's true, "work harder" only gets me from a 1 to a 3 or 4, while the others go from 5 to 10.

body:
> There is a good chance you are locking yourself out of potential stuffs you are good at because of your hesitance.

I'm not hesitant at anything. I've tried everything that interests me. I've been doing them for years before I even realized this. I'm only "good" at them in the sense that I can copy others and impress those who never even tried. But when it comes to reality I can never amount to anything, and I've denied it for too long and it never did me any good.

Can I make a shitty half-baked attempt in 200x the time it takes someone else to produce an utterly *flawless* result? Yes, but that's not really worth it. There are gods in this world, don't lie to me we've all seen it, and then there are normal people, and then there are those for whom everything goes wrong.

If you don't believe me:

[I'm a programmer](https://github.com/CrystalVulpine) but even with way more time I'll never match what these guys just do naturally:

https://github.com/foxite

https://github.com/gingkathfox

https://github.com/lithiumjs

None of my ruqqus or reddit communities have been successful, but people like stars_in_blue_major and no_chill and AddictedReddit have a damn near 100% success rate.

This person both learned 5 languages fluently and several others decently in only a year and is also really good at drawing: https://www.reddit.com/user/frummerfuchs/

I enjoy wittiness and humor but can't do it myself, yet many others can. I'm also not very creative at all, even though that's exactly what I like doing. Before I went through puberty this wasn't the case, and it seems to have affected most guys.

Some people know every corner of the internet and my only resource is still google so I can never find anything.

I like making posts but I can never find any content that's not already famous and when I do I take an hour coming up with the blandest titles. Check +foxes, my own guild, where the other posters have no issues with this.

I like learning and reading a lot but I just don't know anything still. Even in my biggest field of interest the other people are talking gibberish terms to me. From my perspective it feels like they're omniscient and just know everything about everything automatically.

[And don't even get me started on sfrohne/cqtz](https://ruqqus.com/+uslashremoved/post/695h/sfrohne-permanently-banned-for-linking-to/lwd4)

At this point all my efforts have been vain and I don't see any denying that I just got unlucky genes and my lot in life is to be a miserable medicore little shit forever. Even happiness has been proven to be mostly *determined* by your genes. I tried to deny it for years but it just didn't work.

I'm not hesitant at anything. I've tried everything that interests me. I've been doing them for years before I even realized this. I'm only "good" at them in the sense that I can copy others and impress those who never even tried. But when it comes to reality I can never amount to anything, and I've denied it for too long and it never did me any good.

Can I make a shitty half-baked attempt in 200x the time it takes someone else to produce an utterly flawless result? Yes, but that's not really worth it. There are gods in this world, don't lie to me we've all seen it, and then there are normal people, and then there are those for whom everything goes wrong.

body: Says the talent savant. I don't think most people blessed with a tons of gifts understand that some people simply don't have it in them, as they've never experienced real, permanent failure, only the bumps on the road to success. No matter how hard you try, if your brain is fundamentally not wired for something you're not going to be able to do it. It may be possible to succeed with determination in movies but in real life talent plays a much bigger role than our egalitarian minds like to admit. In fact I think it is *the* biggest determining factor (and science backs up my observation). Practice always makes you improve but in reality it's only a marginal difference, the biggest factor is indeed how much natural talent you were lucky enough to inherit. Fortunately most people are drawn to what they're good at, and if that's nothing they're content to just sit back and hang around and passively enjoy life. I definitely inherited that, but unfortunately something went wrong for me and I'm desiring to do the exact opposite of what I was primed for.

body: I've done things for 10 years too, and I still suck at them. Of course you weren't as good at first, but it's overall still way better. Skill ceilings do exist, and at some point you just can't get any better, or if you do it's extremely marginal. And that maxed-out level is different for everyone, and that's what talent is. If your brain is not wired to be able to do something, you will never be able to do it right. It's like having the wrong tools for a job.

I don't even really think most of my "talents" were innate. I just followed what I found enjoyable and pursued them.

Hell, my "art talent" is really just one monolith of a decade's worth of failures and missteps, i even doubted myself so many times in the past and even still do today. 

I think the point im trying to make is that failure or mistakes aren't reason alone to admit defeat. They're lessons. and well... without failure, we know not where we need to improve or have reason to change.

And that's something i don't exactly make any money on, as I do not create for others for money at this time.

parent.body:
Doesn't sound like you've been taking the right drugs. But no worries, put that aside.

I know its goofy, but have you considered any spiritual practices? Shamanic practices might seem goofy and stupid, but genuine and competent practicioners have a natural talent (plus training) for understanding and accurately interpreting brain waves and the different states they invoke, as well as a knack for practical methods in how to control and alter these states. Here is a link for some info about what activities your brain is primed for in different brainwave frequencies if you aren't familiar:

https://brainworksneurotherapy.com/what-are-brainwaves

I only suggest shamanic practices (ceremonial and ritual type medicines; drumming and other percussion, dancing, chanting, humming etc) because I have had success with methods like that. But there are more modern approaches which I started off using (psychiatry, technology based interpretations of your different stages, EEG's, fMRI's and using pharmacuetical medicines, digital tones, lights, images etc to alter and control states). I went modern to gain a foundational understanding that made logical sense to me, then moved onto a fusion of traditional and modern practices. Give it some consideration if you have no experience.
